non-technical domains i'm also going to be talking about sort of what it has looked like to do
work in sort of the program synthesis and program languages space in the past aiming to work for for end users and
maybe not always landing on something that is usable or useful so i'm going to talk a bit in that context about need
finding to make things that are going to be useful and then formative assessment to actually figure out if things are usable
so i want to start by acknowledging that this talk is going to touch on a bunch of awesome work by my students the folks
in my lab i'm not gonna go through all of them here but i will pop up the pictures
again when we get to to their work uh we have been calling ourselves the the plate lab for uh basically talking

all the good stuff is from them i also want to talk about one of the the primary goals of this lab which is
to bridge the gap with folks from the social sciences who they have various
needs but they don't necessarily know how to do the traditional programming processes
that we would expect from folks to get their automation needs accomplished and the reason i say social science
visionaries here is these are fields that have really long histories sometimes centuries long and they're really
somewhat set in their ways in some cases and so you have to go out and find folks who are willing to try techniques that
might be somewhat riskier start doing work that hasn't necessarily been possible for folks in their space before
and so building really strong close collaborations with folks on the the social science side has been
really critical for our lab and actually getting tools adopted by them and making sure that they are actually useful and
usable for them so that's going to be a thread that runs through today's talk a little quick background on on me and
sort of what has shaped my lab's direction i started from a primarily programming languages background both at
sort of the undergrad level and for the first part of my my grad school but eventually realized that i really
was going to be needing a bunch of hci techniques in order to do the work i wanted to do well
and so one of the big things that i've been thinking about a lot both sort of over the course of my phd and as i've

is in part programming languages are super powerful right as a interac interaction way of actually doing tasks
so a way to interface with some kind of automation it gives users a lot of control it gives
them really powerful extractions and a lot of flexibility then uh on the pl side we've been
developing especially in the last couple of decades some really amazing guardrails right there are ways that we

for if you are giving someone the full flexibility of a language how you make sure that they're actually going to be able to use it in a way that is safe and
effective and then the other thing is there's been all this progress in the program synthesis space which is basically ways
of turning things that are not programs or at least not traditional programs into programs right how do we
take something other than traditional code use it as a specification in order to automatically write the programs that
they're going to need and so those are all techniques that we think can be really helpful to to a lot of the the hci goals
and i want to quickly talk about the the things that the pl side should be drawing on more from the hci site right
all of these are things that it's not that they've never been explored but it's things that we think are under explored in these spaces so far
so the things that we're really excited for pl people to start doing more and i'm going to emphasize a lot this first
one a lot of need finding right we've had this long history of people saying okay this is a problem that i personally have
faced in my programming languages journey and therefore i'm going to make
this tool that will be useful for compiler optimizers the 10 compiler optimizer writers who are working inside
the c internal scene right whatever the case is which absolutely awesome problems it's good
that someone is working on that but that's not the only way to to find important problems important needs and
we're really excited about people starting to basically go out and look for the kinds of things that programming languages and
tools can tackle out in the world another thing is we figured out that you know not every programming languages
researcher is willing to actually run formative user studies and so if we want to make it practical for these folks to
actually make good design choices in the process of developing languages of developing tools we really are going to
have to give them some kind of a shortcut and we think that's probably going to end up having to be behavioral theory if we can develop enough of it
that folks can start making these decisions without running user studies of their own and then also this idea of iterative
refinement so believe it or not this is not actually super common in mainstream pl often the idea is you start with a goal
you proceed until you have reached that goal you then evaluate it and that's kind of where we land at least on the on the
user evaluation side right there's not a lot of okay let's put this in front of somebody let's see what's working what's not working let's go back let's let's
iterate and so making sure that we're actually getting that kind of formative input we think is is really important and we'd
like to see more of that happening on the pl side okay so those are our three sort of thrusts of things that we are hoping
to have uh showing up more in in programming languages and that's going to shape some of the work that you'll see today

opportunity neighborhoods now the background here is that there are housing voucher programs where the
intention is to give housing vouchers to folks from low-income families
uh if the the place that they are trying to rent is under some kind of rent
threshold right they don't want to overpay because then you can't serve as many families but
you do have to set the rent threshold in such a way that there are actually places in the high opportunity neighborhoods that fall under that rent
threshold and so if you're relying on every 10 years census data and you're in a city where the rents are rising
rapidly this can be pretty tough pretty quickly you end up with a point where the the rent threshold is set in such a way that
only the low income low opportunity neighborhoods are actually accessible below that rent threshold and then you
have unintentionally produced a housing voucher program that is funneling people into those neighborhoods only
so that's not what we want and what the folks in this space realized was that the way they can actually set those thresholds uh in a data guided
way in a way that's actually going to adapt to fast-changing market situations
is to get real-time data from from the web so in this case they realize that craigslist and apartments.com are providing a lot of really uh uh rich
really uh up-to-date data on what are the prices for uh rental units in this
neighborhood versus this neighborhood versus this neighborhood so we wanted to check out first whether is

because they hadn't been able to actually get it so far and so this kicked off a set of need

what's the things that it's happening and one of the things she noticed was that repetitive demonstrations were a big obstacle for people if they could

it's really frustrating to go back and give my seventh repetitive demonstration and over here she was uh this is

of failure and semi-success stories we're seeing that even though we're starting
to have vbe tools it's not enough to have them be programming by example or programming by demonstration that's not
enough to actually make them usable so let's diagnose real quick what's going wrong there's actually a common thread running through all three of
these stories so here they were frustrated about giving really repetitive demonstrations here they were confused by the need for
having multiple different kinds of demonstrations that would all come together to produce one program and here they want to get the right answer after
just one example so i think after looking at this you'll say to yourself well it seems like if we could just do
everything from a single demonstration if we only get one example then maybe the user is going to be happy
and so that's what we asked ourselves was could we do pbd with just one demonstration now
doing it with a single demonstration is crazy if you're a program of this person right you look at that specification

demonstration that we actually gave so the observation that ended up driving our approach is that
drafting programs is really hard for these users as it turns out however editing is easy right
they've had this particular set of training in some amount of programming a lot of them have had about one semester
of python or r data analysis even in those spaces where they've had training they don't actually just sit
down with a blank page right they have this blank page syndrome it's very intimidating to sit down with the open editor window and they're not going to
just go ahead and sit down and write out a new data analysis script from scratch but what they are going to do is take
the program that they used in class the program that their collaborator is using and adapt it for the tasks that they're trying to do right now
and so that's basically the observation that we were able to to produce our approach around so
one thing here is we're going to need to make editable programs right calling back to this quote here we really do
if we are going to do it this way we need to make sure that the user can actually read understand and modify the
programs that they're getting back from the synthesizer so what will make the tool usable so
one thing is it has to be single demonstration has to be editable we had definitely not reached that point so far
in the in the pvd history so nope not yet and so our approach here was rather than
doing the traditional pbd workflow where you put in a bunch of demonstrations the synthesis algorithm takes it turns it
into a program then you run the program you pop out the output the user debugs by looking at the output
and thinks about is that the right output if they're not happy with it they put in another demonstration we get rid of that workflow and instead
we do a demonstrate once revised anytime workflow where the idea is the user puts in one demonstration the synthesis
algorithm produces a program it may not be exactly the program the user is going to want in the end
but it's close enough that the user can now edit it until it reaches the point where the the user is happy with it so this is the the single demonstration
element this is the editable program element that's what we think we need in order to reach usability
so let's talk quickly about why one demo really is so much better than two demonstrations so obviously we've already talked about
the fact that it makes for happy successful users another thing is it actually changes the constraints on us the developers of the
synthesizer so one of the big challenges in synthesis is if you have to reach every single point in the program space
that's a really really massive search space and it's really hard to actually do that so we get to relax that because
we can just reach some of the points in the program space as long as they are close enough via edits
to the program that the user is going to want in the end another thing is it changes all the extra infrastructure we have to build up
around the synthesizer so we don't have to do this ambiguity detection layer or this demonstration solicitation interface anymore
and then another thing is it changes the programs that you can actually use programming by demonstration for so
whereas in the past you really couldn't do long-running programs now we can and so why couldn't we do long-running programs
in the past well if the way that you're going to debug it is by running it looking at the output
seeing if the output is right and if your web automation program that you're trying to run is going to run for you know three days
boy that's going to be really hard to actually land on the one that you were looking for fortunately in this case where we're
actually presenting them programs that they can look at they can debug it does become reasonable for them to actually debug even very long running programs
so the way that we are going to reach this this door approach is by developing usable drafting tools and learnable
languages of course these are also usable outside useful and usable outside of uh dora workflows we just happen to
be talking about them in the context of this one workflow so on the usable drafting tools the techniques that we ended up using in developing
were program synthesizers dialog based program augmentation interfaces and then on the learnable languages side
we spent a lot of time on reverse compilation and bi-level dsls and some custom language abstractions i'm not

goal 3 today let's start with how we synthesize complex programs from a single demonstration
so we knew that what users need this was based on some of that need finding work with with real folks in this space
uh we knew that people needed multi-load data so this is stuff that is accessed by clicking interacting with forms doing
widget interactions right all the stuff that you do when you're interacting with the web on a day-to-day basis they need to do in order to collect their data
it's also looking for hierarchical data so the data they want isn't just give me the list of all authors it's give me the
list of all authors and all of their papers right we have all of this hierarchical type data that they're looking to get
and so those are the constraints that we definitely needed to make in order for the the tool to come out useful to them
unfortunately this is going to be a little bit hard so we know that we need to actually get this kind of data we
definitely know that the tools that were out there were not there yet um but why is it actually hard well
if you're a program synthesizer you're probably already getting a program synthesis person you're probably already
getting nervous when you realize that you're going to need nested loops right the nested loops are sort of one of the
the banes of program synthesis in general and if you think about it as sort of
how it expands the space of programs that you're searching this makes a lot of sense right so if you think about only the programs that have no loops
well that is a massive set obviously but it's somewhat manageable it's somewhat reasonable in size
if you start thinking about all the programs that have one loop well you're already up to a much bigger set that's starting to look a little nerve-wracking
and in fact a lot of program synthesizers cannot have handle programs that even have one loop
if you're allowing multiple loops boy now it's really getting intense the search space is massive and it's going
to be pretty tough to actually search that space and so we hit this little fork in the road where we could go down the path of
trying to make a smarter faster synthesizer right this is the thing that people have traditionally tried when they have tackled this problem afresh
or is there some other way what else could we do other than just try to make a smarter faster synthesizer
and so the the thing that we eventually started thinking about was there are lots of different demonstrations that
you could give in order to show a human user the kinds of data that you're trying to collect so
in our little working example here maybe they go ahead and play around with a couple of the papers from this author
and then they show the list page that author appeared and they scrape the various things that they're going to
want that's a good demonstration it would probably serve to explain to a human user what you're trying to actually
collect but another way you can do it is the way we did it in the the demo that you saw where first we collect
information about that first author then we collect information about the first paper by that first author these are two very different
demonstrations and as it turns out one of them is going to make it much easier for the program synthesizer to actually
do their job so if we allow all possible demonstrations we really don't have any better approach than just searching
through the whole space of programs until we land on one that produces the data that the user has collected
on the other hand if we restrict it to demonstrations like the one on the right we can be a bit smarter
